H0.text: The schoolyard has few trees is the fact about Clara's schoolyard that most helps her claim that her school is in a desert.

H1.text: The schoolyard has rocks and sand, which most helps Clara’s claim that her school is in a desert.

H2.text: The schoolyard gets warm in the summer, which most helps Clara’s claim that her school is in a desert.

H3.text: The schoolyard gets little rain during the year is the fact that most helps Clara claim that her school is in a desert.

A4.text: The characteristics of hot deserts include high temperatures in summer; greater evaporation than precipitation, usually exacerbated by high temperatures, strong winds and lack of cloud cover;

A5.text: Deserts generally receive less than 250 mm (10 in) of precipitation each year.

A6.text: Most desert/arid climates receive between 25 and 200 mm (1 and 8 in) of rainfall annually.

A7.text: Hot deserts are among the hottest, the driest, and the sunniest places on Earth.

A8.text: Daily variations in temperature can be as great as 22 °C (40 °F) or more, with heat loss by radiation at night being increased by the clear skies.

A9.text: One of the driest places on Earth is the Atacama Desert.

A10.text: Death Valley reports 60 mm of rainfall annually, but in 40 months between 1931 and 1934 a total of just 16 mm of rainfall was measured.

A11.text: Hot desert climates have hot, dry summers with temperatures typically between 29 and 35 °C (84 and 95 °F), and midday readings of 43–46 °C (109–115 °F) are common.

A12.text: Many deserts, such as the Sahara, are hot year-round.

A13.text: Ecoregions in this habitat type vary greatly in the amount of annual rainfall they receive, usually less than 250 millimetres (10 in) annually except in the margins.
